title: Walks around Bletchingley Walking Route

images.title: Ian Capper / The Manse
images.caption: The Manse. 17th century grade II listed building opposite Castle Square.

images.title: The Prince Albert public house, Bletchingley by David Martin, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Prince Albert public house

images.title: Church of St Mary the Virgin, Bletchingley by Ian Capper, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Church of St Mary the Virgin. The church dates back to the Medieval period along with several of the other buildings in the village.

images.title: Rib / Lake in Mercers Country Park
images.caption: Lake in Mercers Country Park. Large lake used for water sports. The dark patches near the lower edge of photo are big carp in the shallow water where a slipway meets the lake

images.title: Tony Gillam / Earlswood Lakes
images.caption: Earlswood Lakes. This is the top lake of the two lakes on a nice clear sunny day. The lake itself is not very deep and has an abundance of wildlife. It is a very quiet, relaxing spot, where you can either take in the views or go for walk around the lakes. The walks takes you through the woods where there are more hidden surprises. Bursting with wild life, you may catch a glimpse of a rare species, a migrant bird. An ideal nature reserve, easily accessed from either the M25 or M23, good free parking, with refreshment available.

images.title: Hywel Williams / The Moors Nature Reserve
images.caption: The Moors Nature Reserve. The Moors Nature Reserve. This nature reserve is a wetland habitat that has been restored by the Surrey Wild Life Trust. The site is located a short distance to the north west of the village.

images.title: Redhill Common by Ian Capper, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Redhill Common

description: This fine Surrey based village is a worthy place to visit for walkers and historians. The village includes a conservation area with many medieval buildings of interest. It is also located on the Greensand Ridge which can be explored on foot on the Greensand Way long distance trail. This circular walk from the village uses part of the trail to visit nearby Redhill where you can explore Redhill and Earlswood Common. The commons are a popular place for local walks with good footpaths and the pretty Earlswood Lakes to see. The walk then follows a traffic free section of National Cycle Route 21 to visit the wildlife rich Moors Nature Reserve and Mercers Country Park. Another local highlight the park includes a large boating lake and some pleasant walking trails. Scroll down for a list of other walks near and around the village. For more details on the historic buildings, local amenities and neighbouring settlements see the informative wikipedia page.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Bletchingley Arms is located on the High Street at postcode RH1 4PE. They serve good quality food and have a lovely spacious pub garden for warmer weather.

display_address: Castle Square, Bletchingley, Tandridge, Surrey, England, RH1 4LG, United Kingdom
